image.altText: A post-impressionist painting of a green field with farmhouses behind, three with red roofs and one with a blue roof.

props.synopsis: The blue roof, or Farm at Le Pouldu, by post-impressionist Paul Gauguin is purchased by the National Gallery of Australia, making it the first of his paintings to enter an Australian public collection.

title.children: National Gallery of Australia spends $9.8 million on painting by controversial artist Paul Gauguin

image.altText: A bronze statue of a woman smiling.

props.synopsis: Susan Ryan was the first female Labor minister and the first female minister for women during her career as part of the Hawke government in the 1980s.

title.children: Statue of late senator Susan Ryan, who championed women in politics, unveiled in Canberra

image.altText: GPS tracker on an ankle with person wearing a black shoe.

props.synopsis: The Canberra Liberals are proposing that some serious offenders who have been granted bail should be fitted with electronic monitoring.

title.children: Opposition proposes ankle bracelets for those accused of 'serious offences' on bail in the ACT

image.altText: A woman seated at a table holding a photograph of a younger woman.

props.synopsis: Damage to a woman's grave site was discovered by her husband and six-year-old son on her birthday, when they went to visit the Gungahlin Cemetery earlier this week.

title.children: Police looking for three men after graves allegedly robbed at Canberra cemetery

image.altText: Ali Khamenei sits in a chair and speaks with Ismail Haniyeh and Ziad Nakhaleh, who sit on a nearby couch in a formal room.

props.synopsis: Specifics about how Hamas political leader Ismail Haniyeh and Hezbollah commander Fuad Shukr were killed on Tuesday are scarce, but one thing is certain: the two high-profile hits will further destabilise the Middle East.

title.children: Two global assassination plots in 24 hours: Is this the day that changes the Middle East?

image.altText: Foreign minister Penny Wong faces the media in Adelaide. 2024-04-06 10:04:00

props.synopsis: Australians have been urged to leave Lebanon immediately as the foreign minister emphasises the Beirut airport could close if the situation worsens.

title.children: Foreign Minister Penny Wong warns Australians in Lebanon to leave immediately

image.altText: A man in a store, wearing a cap and bumbag.

props.synopsis: The FBI, AFP and Malaysian police have all failed to charge Adrian Katong. In the meantime the phishing syndicate operator is leading a life of luxury and becoming more brazen in his operations that have taken millions of dollars from Australians.

title.children: Adrian Katong ran a one-stop shop for phishing scams. Here's how he was tracked down

image.altText: A black sign with 'CFMEU Victoria' written on it, hanging on a construction site.

props.synopsis: The application could reach the Federal Court as early as this afternoon.

title.children: Fair Work set to apply for CFMEU administrators as crossbenchers tell federal government to go further

image.altText: A man wearing a green shirt sits in ablue chair and looks out

props.synopsis: The Matildas are on the lookout for a new head coach after Football Australia ended months of speculation and confirmed Tony Gustavsson's contract would not be extended.

title.children: Gustavsson era over as Matildas hunt for new coach

image.altText: Jess Fox, Favour Ofili and Iga Swiatek

props.synopsis: Jess Fox's C1 win proves to be eight years in the making, Nigeria's officials are in hot water over a horrible error ahead of the 100m sprint, and the best women's tennis player in the world finds herself in an opponent's crosshairs.

title.children: Olympic quick hits: Incredible picture shows Fox is an idol, blunder denies Nigerian track star, and Iga Swiatek blasted over 'fakeness'

image.altText: A horse and rider pass along a track with the Chateau de Versailles in the background

props.synopsis: Paris has thrown its doors open to the world for these Olympic Games, and that has meant allowing modern intrusion to some of history's most storied places. At Chateau de Versailles that invasion is felt most keenly, but somehow has become something magical.

title.children: At Versailles, the Olympics intrude on history and create something magical

image.altText: The fence and mailbox at the front of a property with a burnt out car in the background.

props.synopsis: A senior Queensland police officer has told an inquest why he made the decision to send in officers to save a young constable before specialised teams arrived.

title.children: Wieambilla inquest hears police officer was 'hunted' by shooters before her rescue

image.altText: Tony Burke in focus standing next to Anthony Albanese out of focus

props.synopsis: Labor is well aware that there are no shortage of headaches to contend with as the election looms. But can Anthony Albanese's cabinet reshuffle lessen the pain?

title.children: Albanese's cabinet reshuffle was akin to shaking a snow globe – the pieces are the same but slightly rearranged

image.altText: Menstruation products

props.synopsis: More than 60 per cent of girls, women, and gender-diverse people who menstruate are struggling to buy basic period products amid soaring costs of living, Australia's largest body of data on periods has found.

title.children: 'Unspoken poverty' among people who menstruate forces use of makeshift sanitation products

image.altText: A view of the harbour.

props.synopsis: The Beijing-controlled government in Hong Kong is luring mainland Chinese to live in the city to shore up the city's faltering economy.

title.children: In a tiny $3m flat, I'm witnessing China's plans to replace the Hong Kongers who fled

image.altText: A man in a suit sitting and speaking, with his arms raised, gesturing

props.synopsis: Donald Trump uses an appearance at a gathering of Black journalists to suggest his election opponent, Kamala Harris, has switched racial identities from Indian to Black.

title.children: Donald Trump suggests Kamala Harris 'happened to turn Black'

image.altText: Silhouettes of five people are coloured and laid out in a graphic.

props.synopsis: The disability community bared its soul at the royal commission. Now the initial response has been unveiled, some are wondering whether the pain was really worth it, write Nas Campanella and Evan Young.

title.children: The disability royal commission ran for 4.5 years. Within hours of the response, anger was already building

image.altText: Felicity Chafer-Smith The Torch artwork

props.synopsis: Programs like The Torch in Victoria want to break the cycle of incarceration for First Nations people.

title.children: With Indigenous incarceration increasing, community-led groups say they've got answers

image.altText: A regional express airplane

props.synopsis: Rex's risky gamble to compete with major airlines on intercity routes may see it back where it started, albeit with greater financial problems.

title.children: Rex chose to gamble during the pandemic. It will take weeks to know how much its lost

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks towards the camera with other people surrounding him.

props.synopsis: According to the Productivity Commission, five of 19 Closing the Gap targets are currently 'on track'. That's where the good news ends.

title.children: The new inflation figures brought relief for Albanese, but another set of numbers were depressing reading

image.altText: Alanna Kennedy of Australia reacts after losing to the USA during the Paris Olympic Games

props.synopsis: After three underwhelming performances saw them crash out at the group stage for the first time since 2000, the Matildas' Olympic campaign must be a reality check for the Australian game.

title.children: Matildas' Olympic exit is the reality check Australia has been bracing for

image.altText: A composite image showing Linday Reynolds on the left and Brittany Higgins on the right

props.synopsis: With mediation attempts and extensions of olive branches falling flat, Senator Linda Reynolds's defamation trial against Brittany Higgins and her partner David Sharaz will kick off tomorrow.

title.children: The very public spat between Brittany Higgins and Linda Reynolds is about to be heard in court, and there's a lot at stake

image.altText: A woman with long, dark brown hair speaks to the camera with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: Senator Jacqui Lambie reveals the names of some of the members on her until-now secretive party board and that she became president of it two weeks ago.

title.children: Jacqui Lambie reveals party's board members and 'loose' Monday night meetings

image.altText: The historic Billson's Brewery with two chimneys and a faded antique sign on the side

props.synopsis: Thirty redundancies were announced at the Victorian brewery on Wednesday with 50 staff remaining employed to continue trading while the administrators restructure the company.

title.children: Billson's administrators 'optimistic' buyer can be found for historic brewery

image.altText: A man celebrates winning a gold medal with his arms wide on the top of the podium

props.synopsis: Kyle Chalmers believes he was bested by a clean racer. But that did little to satiate Pan who has accused the Aussie star of a poolside snub.

title.children: 'I trust that': Bested Chalmers confident Chinese record-holder swam drug-free race

image.altText: A woman holds a placard showing 10,000, the Bitcoin logo and Thai characters.

props.synopsis: About 50 million Thais are set to get a "digital wallet" containing 10,000 baht ($420) as part of a $21 billion cash handout scheme that has been criticised as costly, unsustainable and detrimental to Thailand's already struggling economy.

title.children: Thai citizens invited to sign up for controversial $21 billion cash handout plan

image.altText: Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, (R), the alleged mastermind of the September 11 attacks, speaks with his defence lawyer

props.synopsis: The letter to families of the September 11 victims says the guilty pleas could be entered as soon as next week or within the next few months.

title.children: Man accused of plotting September 11 attacks reaches plea deal alongside two accomplices

image.altText: A white man screams in the face of a police officer wearing riot gear.

props.synopsis: The Merseyside Police force says the teenager, who has not been named because of his age, faces three counts of murder and 10 counts of attempted murder over the attack.

title.children: Police charge 17-year-old with three counts of murder over Southport stabbing

image.altText: a young woman wearing a burnt orange blazer and white top.

props.synopsis: A senior female member of a NSW regional branch of the Liberal Party resigns over claims she was told to go on a crash diet and to make way for male candidates.

title.children: NSW mayoral candidate quits Liberal Party after 'crash diet' jibe

image.altText: The members of The 1975 dressed in suits against a white background.

props.synopsis: Authorities in Kuala Lumpur halted the three-day Good Vibes Festival in 2023 after videos showed The 1975's frontman Matty Healy kissing his band mate.

title.children: An onstage kiss could end up costing this British band $3.76 million

image.altText: An open for inspection sign at a Brisbane apartment, behind it people are entering a building

props.synopsis: Australian house prices rise 0.5 per cent in July, despite Melbourne, Hobart and Darwin recording a fall in values during the past three months, according to new data released by CoreLogic.

title.children: What July's house price data tells us about where values are headed

image.altText: A man looks at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: A tech rally on Wall Street has sent Australian stocks higher, while the Federal Reserve has left US interest rates unchanged but indicated it could begin easing monetary policy in September if inflation cools. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX rises, US Fed signals upcoming rate cut

image.altText: The name "Albermarle" lettered on the side of a building.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of workers are expected to lose their jobs at Albemarle's Kemerton lithium plant as the miner responds to further volatility in the global market.

title.children: 300 jobs to be lost as US lithium giant makes further cuts at WA plant

image.altText: A selfie of a smiling young woman reclined on a leather sofa, by a dog resting it's head on her shoulder.

props.synopsis: At the end of 2020, counsellor Caroline Kell hit a breaking point. She asked herself, "do I want to continue to live my life like this?" The answer was no.

title.children: 'Reformed busy person' Caroline Kell on cherishing the small moments

image.altText: Two men, both with blue shirts on, one shirt has Straight Outta Newtown visible on it. Both standing on a verandah

props.synopsis: The author of The Youngest Son, John Byrnes, says his father's reaction to his new novel has left him a "bit spooked". Byrnes told ABC News, scenes he thought he had made up, his dad says, actually happened.

title.children: The Youngest Son author John Byrnes a 'bit spooked' by father's reaction to new novel
